introduction.p: So far, we have examined (for the most part) lump sums - a single amount of money at a single point in time. We now turn to annuities - sequences of payments over time. The payments are to be spaced by equal time intervals (months, years, etc.). Our focus in this course will be on "annuities-certain" -- annuities in which the payments are certain to take place. In your later actuarial exams, you will relax this assumption, meaning that the payments will be random variables.

In this chapter and the chapter that follows, we assume that the payments in our annuities are constant. In actuarial language, we say that we have "level payments." If there are n payments of K and the effective periodic interest rate is \iota, then we denote (a) the accumulated value of the annuity (immediately following the final payment) by Ks_{\angln \iota}, and (b) the present value of the annuity (one period prior to the first payment) by Ka_{\angln \iota}.
